textDisplay:
I still do like the game, but I agree. in almost a decade, there is little excuse not to put some people in the development cycle towards tinkering about prolonging the game, you know, In a Game About New Game Pluses and playing the game multiple times, as well as several fucking times on your main.. That's not an issue just with DS3, but all of the demon's dark souls blood games, all of them share this issue and something as old as Diablo 2, is far more replayable.
There is a limit to it sure, but you can play it for hundreds upon hundreds of hours and not get bored.

a couple of things that D2 I feel did better is, enemies becoming their own nightmare, less NG+ meant more focus and concentrated effort upon giving the enemies some truly demonic powers.. and speeds.. The game gets really hard in Nightmare, but it gets extremely fucking hard in Hell, when enemies start blitzing at the speed of lightning through the screen, with auras fucking you up, enchanted properties, strong and agile champions, as well as champion minions, etc.

2nd thing, items. This is arguably the best part of the D2 nightmare and hell, especially the latter, finding the unique items took many, many, many years for people and having those accessible for the parts of the game they would make sense to exist in, either Nightmare or Hell, that makes it all better, because it gives those portions a reason to be played, other than for bragging rights, which is how the series here is.

3rd thing, Uber bosses. That's the thing this demon's dark souls blood series could've done and hell, they even showed they could do it, with Bloodborne's Chalice Dungeons. It's not the best way of doing, nor how I would want it, the better way would be sequence breaking within the main game and finding other areas, or other bosses, made specifically to be fought in that difficulty, or just 1 optional area at least if not that, even though a couple more for the challenge's sake would be a just reward to players who put so much effort into the NG+ -es of these games.
For an example, think of something like this almost hidden secret in the main game, something that can be accessed right now. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u3xkM700bSk This is cool, this gives us Real reasons to play NG+.



To me, that kind of rewarding of exploration and dedication is very important, that's what initially made me put through the effort into Diablo 2's later modes when I was a teen and it's what initially made these games worth playing in the first time I was playing them and I've been struggling since to find interest in continuing NG+ on any of them,  unless the motivation is the desire not to leave these games, which is really depressing if that's how some people justify it, isn't it?..
NG+ in almost all of them seems rather barren and lost in meaning when you already have all of the items, a lot of the game is gone once you've already acquired all of those items and that's cool that you have that, but you're set on a Hard limit too with your stats and how far your weapons can go. What I'm talking about here is, it could have been much better and I think FromSoftware have had more than enough years to tinker and go crazy with such ideas, or maybe they just never had the suggestions, or the thought never crossed their minds, but the one thing I can say in their defense is that, in some cases, they tried and it doesn't mean that I hate the games, it's just more of a missed golden opportunity to make these games, the most played games of for the next 10 or so years from now, as well as cementing our trust into them for any future games to come.

textDisplay: As someone who is going through the remastered version of Dark Souls 1 i actually disagree with you in terms of the bosses, the variety of bosses in DS1 to me is staggering, im not completely finished with the game yet but i can already tell that the enemies and bosses all seem unique compared to dark souls 3, most of the bosses in ds3 seem mostly the same, the arenas that you fight the bosses in are great but the bosses themselves dont have that awe factor that ds1 has, the gaping dragon in ds1 is a great example of this to me, i remember watching it poke its small head above the ledge and thinking that it was going to be an easy fight, but then as soon as it crawled up onto the ledge it took my breath away with how shocking the reveal was, in ds3 there are none of these reveals that take your breath away, the only boss that i can think of in ds3 that can come close to the bosses of ds1 is the abyss watchers. Personally i perfer the fact you can warp to and from all bonfires in ds3 but i can appreciate the world design in ds1, another thing that sticks out to me in ds1 is the enemy and location variety, you can go from fighting the hollowed knights of lordran to fighting a giant hydra in minutes. Which is another thing that sticks out to me, some of the standard enemies of ds1 could stand out as a great boss in ds3, the stone nights, the hydra, the hell knight dragon. All of these enemies and more would stand out and be completely unique compared to the standard enemies and bosses of ds3. All of this is just my opinion and what i can think of off the top of my head. My grammar may not be the best because i typed this pretty fast but my points still stand.

The first thing im going to say is that youre wrong about the build diversity and ive NEVER had to wait more than a few minutes to pvp with anyone. Not to mention that i play xbox wich has way less people than pc. About the build diversity: yes, a lot of the weapons have the same functionality, but that doesnt mean they arent uniqe. and most of the weapons that do have the same functionality can still be used in a different way for a specific build. Dark souls three is the last game of the series so of course it will have every weapon from the previous games and it has PLENTY of its own arsenal of weaponry. Especially when you count the DLC weapons. That being said, i pvp all the time and have never seen 2 of the same builds.

Concerning the level design: I absolutely HATE when people shit on DS3 level design and complain that its linear and that its not interconnected. Those are both false accusations. It is linear at the very beggining(the whole teleport thing) but once you get to the forrest where you have 2 paths to branch off from its pretty much open. Not to mention the numerous side paths in the (linear) parts of the game that lead to very useful npc's and various items that will help  you along the way. And upon doing a recent playthrough, i found that it is actually really interconnected--not like ds1 that connected the entire world(well, the first half of it) but rather each area is interconnected to itself.

And i know the final boss doesnt explain much, but he is a representation of the player character in every form and he is (basically) a manifestation of Gwyn. That being said, i couldnt ask for a better ending boss to the (base) game.

textDisplay:
I never played it, or any other souls game. Just bloodborne. But damn did the ending of this video jerk some tears. About getting back up after being knocked down. That’s one of the things I love about bloodborne, and one of the things I struggle with most in life. When I play it, it feels like I can escape and rest my mind, achieving something. And those simple achievements and moments are all I really get right now. 

It’s not just about escaping either. It’s about inspiration. I know the feeling of learning songs on an instrument, or dedicating yourself to school, a hobby, a person- Never have I played a game that made me reflect on who I truly am. That immersion is beyond story telling, beyond entertainment, and beyond delusion. 

The reason why bloodborne has such an impact on me is because the environment felt similar to real life. Having to fight battles alone, and sometimes, getting help. Sometimes getting destroyed by others, or becoming too cocky, too lazy, discouraged.. Most of all, having to watch the world burn around you. Even if it’s the world inside your head, or events that pulled you into some pretty demanding situations. 

This might be one hell of a crazy comment to some people, but to others, they might understand clear as day. The way life is for me feels as real, as saddening, as lonely, hopeless, and just as challenging as the real world is.

I think, the souls approach to lore isn't as effective as it is, when it's applied to the 3rd game in a row in the same world, alongside the convolution offered by 2, we've learned how to approach such stories. Bloodborne was a fresh new world, where we had to construct a new interpretation of a new world. Here, you're analyzing the story...in context of two other stories. 
Thus I posit, that the souls storytelling, while effective in engaging the audience, gets a lot of diminishing returns upon sequelization.

textDisplay:
but... there's more build diversity in ds3 than bloodborne... i mean, just the fact you get 2 more slots for left and right hand weaponry, and that you can use whatever you want on which hand(can't use a gun on your right hand in bb) increases the amount of possible builds  by... well, a ton.
i mean, is what you said at 17:50 a bad thing? it meant you had try lots of different things till you found what you really loved, that's added playtime and it's not like you hated what you did before finding your favorite right? for me while originally i would've said the farron greatsword, i keep finding myself coming back to multi-type spellcasting weaponry: crystal chime, white haired talisman, demon scar and so on, do a strenght build? put on some rings and use the crystal chime, int build? put on a faith ring and use that demon scar, being able to do whatever i want whenever i want just attracts me, the other day i tried using two shields in pvp, with one being a skill shield and the other a parry shield, people had no clue when i'd be parrying and it worked!
...until i miss two riposte after the other.
but that's beside the point, the point is that while ds3 may not allow as much of an interesting stat invastment as ds1 and 2, it still givens more variety than bb in both stat investment and build(as in equipment) variety, and it also has more equipment build variety than ds1, although it depends on cases, this is mainly due to the slots rather than the movesets of offhand weaponry(which is something ds1 actually does better, love the estoc parries)
quality over quantity in my opinion only works when this doesn't undermine build variety, in bb, build variety is nothing but choosing your tools and your main and offhand weapon, and that's it, that's boring for me, i want dynamicity not only in the movements, but in the choice during the fight too, in ds3 i could start with a millwood greatbow, follow up with a shield and farron greatsword, but not use it but instead parry with it, go to the acquamarine dagger, do a bunch of damage, than going to a crystal chime, do force if they were still alive and then use soul greatsword, farron hail and/or homing crystal soulmass.
you could never do such an unpredictable combo in bb, maybe in ds1 if you were really quick with item swap, but no way in bb.
as for ds2... well, i never played it, so i can't really talk about it.

THIS kind of build variety is what kept me coming back to ds3, finding out what equipments i could combo and how i could be the most unpredictable regardless of which stats i chose(also poison is quite good if you keep at 1v1s, in pvp t's bleed that it's useless) bb instead i got and barely finished once or twice, you try a couple weapons and that's the game, no comboing, no pvp, the dungeons are boring  and the areas are all linear and/or frustrating(at least they're not frustrating in ds3 with the exception of the ringed city) and in ds1 it's just... well, i didn't even beat gwyn honestly, i was ok with just reaching him.

textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2 is twice as long as 3, and with its convoluted layout and optional pathing (not to mention immediate NG+ stuff using Bonfire Ascetics), I was much more confused about where to go than any Souls game.  And that confusion lasted my first two playthroughs.  5 times through, and with confidence, I still find I am missing certain things sometimes that prevent my progression, which previously was done through brute force basically, because what triggers certain things isn't always clear. (On my 4th, I was dumbfounded when Nashandra didn't show up after the Throne W&D fight. And Aldia never showed up either afterward,  which I avow not to let happen this 5th time, NG++).  
       I loved DaS1 up til Anor Londo (best part of any game I've played), like AL, and find the rest irritating to the point that I don't really like to play the game.  I've never played more than half of NG+, on 5 toons.  When I realized I loved DaS2 more than DaS1 was at a point in which my head had been hurting for several sessions just trying to figure out where to go and what to do next.  It was lovely.  I have to look past its graphical inferiorites, which is easy, because it is a massively fun GAME. So many route choices (again, Bonfire Ascetics), so many viable PvE and PvP builds, it just makes for a lot of fun because of how such a variety of options can be expressed in your toon, aesthetic, and such when co-oping.  This is because, over the course of a few New Game Plusses (BAs!), your toon will have progressed through those cycles in myriad ways differently than everyone you meet.  This means you meet a lot of people doing they own thang. It's cool.  Plus the weighty, tactical, slower pace of DaS2 just fuckin' works for PvP IMO.  Join the Blues and you won't even have to worry about opening up the World to invade everywhere.  (Ask if you want a hot 2018 tip on constant CBEO invasion, 20-30 in just a few hours. (It's using the Name-Engraved Ring btw [8,900,000 Soul Memory/ Agape Ring FTW).  
       I wish DaS2 was more thorough in fleshing out the environmental details like 3 (In some ways this actually makes DaS2's Chameleon spell a more fun spell to play with and against).  But when I want to play a multiplayer game for fun, its Numero Dos, Todo El Pinche Dia!  I'm even a Blue Sentinel who doesn't use Wrath of the Gods. So, yeah, it kinda is just for the fun of it.

textDisplay: I don’t get why people care about a game being linear or not. They both have upsides and downsides. Linear is less immersive, but is simplistic and nearly impossible to get lost in. On the opposite end of the spectrum, it can be very immersive and eye opening, but back tracking and getting lost can get annoying. I typically think it makes more sense to do what fits the actual world. The first half of DSIII is linear, but it makes sense. It’s the ROAD of sacrifices. It wouldn’t make sense if it wasn’t linear. However, after the abyss watchers, or arguably carthus, it would make sense to switch to a less linear style. Maybe I can understand why irithyll has like a church gateway to anor londo, but why the fuck is there a gateway through carthus to irithyll? It doesn’t make sense for it to exist, and the drastic change from swap to snowy mountains is jarring, especially because the environmental design is so good and begs attention. It is fixed afterwards though, because of the teleports back to the dancer and upper lothric. However, I don’t understand how anyone was ever supposed to live in lothric. The cities don’t have a city structure. Also what the hell is upper lothric supposed to be use for? Is it residential? Is it military? If so, what is it trying to protect or fight? The city? I personally think that the environmental design, one of DSIIIs biggest achievements, is also a massive shortcoming.

textDisplay:
DKS3 is what killed Dark Souls for me. I have been playing the series since 2011 and all I wanted out of the last game was a good conclusion to the story (considering it's the final one), and what did we get? The same fucking endings since the first game. The idea for the story in DKS3 itself is quite good because it follows the paths of the descendants of Gwyn but it was poorly put together and overly convoluted and I think a lot of it was laziness on From's part. They knew everyone would buy it regardless of it's flaws (which they did, obviously). The game is also extremely linear and one of the greatest strengths of the series itself is supposed to be it's non-linear Metroidvania style of 3D world. It is inherently the weakest Souls game, it looks pretty but it's empty and lacks any real soul to it... pun intended.

Miyazaki's true masterpiece is Bloodborne and always will be, unless he makes a new IP similar to it with another great story and atmosphere like BB.

textDisplay:
DS3 definately has a worse UGS class than DS2 though. They are still so slow that enemies would just hit and you would be staggered with weapons much smaller than yours. In DS2 you had poise to negate this effect to some extent. Also no knocking enemies on the ground like in DS2. The 2H strong attacks hardly do any poise damage to most of the enemies where as in DS2 most of the enemies would just fall on the ground with the 2H strong or running attacks. Thus no visible effect of the Fume UGS 10 extra poise damage on enemies. 

The backstab and riposte animations (killing animations not parry ones) were cooler and a little bit more realistic in DS2. The character would stab the enemy's back with the hilt while enemy moves to stop them from moving, kick behind the knees to put on ground and then crush them or a massive slash attack on the back. Riposte was a stab to the chest, light hit with weapon then running the sword through the chest or again crush them. In DS3 riposte and backstab are the same and the enemy in backstab just stops moving for no reason and allows you to hit them. 

The UGS don't particularly have any unique traits to them. For example the Ivory king UGS had a insane reach when 2 handed and produced a magic beam of light for every attack. The Fume UGS had the stability of a greatshield and high damage while having the ability to block and attack at the same time. Pursuer's UGS had a very high counter damage, drakewing UGS had a projectile attack on its strong attack, smelter swords had a blast on stong attack, Kings UGS looked unique (not particularly good) but did extra damage to equipment, etc. DS3 has mostly the RKUGS with a unique movest and properties (higher poise damage and health). 

Weapon arts don't seem to make up for the lack of unique traits possessed by a lot of the DS2 UGS.

textDisplay: A year and a half later, and I still love DS3. I've played it all the way through almost a dozen times and studied the lore extensively, and doing so has been consistently worthwhile and meaningful. I know it inside-out, flaws and shortcomings and all, but something about it just... works for me. Of course, the cost of this was the sacrifice of the originality factor that DS1 and Bloodborne had, which doesn't sit well with everybody, but it does with me. So I'm excited to see Miyazaki heading in new creative directions, now that he's perfected the formula. What comes after that?

You get the key from Leonhard to open the elevator to the Darkwraith in High Wall of Lothric, but under the elevator (in true Dark Souls way) is a secret; A pipe in which you can slide down to the Profaned Capital. From there you can do the following:

textDisplay:
An actual review from someone knew to the franchise: i sunk 700 hours into the game and i felt like i never got any good at pvp or pve. Pve was good, for the first three playthroughs, then got repetitive. The overwhelming commitment to different builds, and ad on top of that *all of them (except quality builds)* were fucking shite. Just made me feel like it wasnt worth it, my first character ended up being over leveled to actually enjoy pvp so i had to creat a new one. Theres nothing wrong with that except for the fact that i was doing it for one specific reason, pvp. Which wasnt a good investment either considering i kept getting *ganked every time i fucking invaded*.
While pvp is absolutely horrible and *very unfair for invaders*, especially for new-time invaders who’ve never, EVER played any previous souls game (like myself). I found that i was constantly at a disadvantage whenever i invaded, or have no advantage at all, as in, not being able invade in the first place. 
Having to invade in the same area to even INVADE got really boring, and got really repetitive really quickly. It really is such a shame to see all the beautiful area’s from has made go to waste because one specific spot lets me invade quicker. 
Invasions was an awful, unfun and unfair experience. While the undead arena is more fair than invading, it too also got *really boring*, and i again felt like i wasnt getting any better at pvp. Yeah i would win some matches here and there, and yes i did get a gold medal a couple of times. But whenever i invaded i felt like all those matches were a waste of time, because i end up getting ganked *again* and all that time in the arena trying to get better at pvp, were wasted.
       While the pvp aspect is fucking horrible lets focus on the pve side of things, pve can be summarized in a couple of words. Here are those words; repetitive, boring, challenging, frustrating and easy.
While pve was fun at first, the charm quickly ran its course and felt dull, lifeless and boring. And yes it is challenging, sometimes it gets frustratingly unfair because of stun mechanics (like pvp), not only that but the fact that some of the bosses were literal jokes if you knew what you were doing (and at this point you do considering that its now newgame+5 and you’ve killed them more times then you can count).
         Ds3 was my favorite game for awhile, then it stopped being that shortly there after. And having ds3 as the last game in the series left me feeling jipped as a customer, i say customer because i personally havent played the previous games and have no real emotional connection to the game or franchise. If you want my honest opinion about ds3, i loved it. But i just got bored of it, and if you guys are right, about your guys’s claim about the *previous* games being better. Then ds3 is a horribly dull, unorganized, visually stunning laughing stock of a sequel.

TL;DR 
if your new to the franchise and is actually looking to buy this game, buy it. Its a great *first-experience rpg* , but dont expect any replay-ability once you’ve beat the game at least three times. Both elements are weak in this game, pvp is unbalanced, frustrating, and boring. Pve is dull, challenging at first, then laughably easy later.
5/10
Mediocre at best.

textDisplay:
I have some issues with this review that you might want to read about, if not then please keep scrolling and pay me no mind. 

I picked up Demon souls at release and ive been a fan of the series ever since so I feel that I have similar knowledge of the franchise as you do. 
A large portion of this video focuses on the leveldesign. You enjoyed the DS1 experience, as did I. You make points about the fact that DS3 doesnt connect its areas in the same way DS1 did and instead we are given the ability to warp.  You also commend DS3 for being a very good game. I agree with most of the things you have to say. But.

NOW my friendly opinion on why this ISNT a good review.

Your sense of eliteism and entitlement shines through this 'review'. You mention it yourself, if you took away the these to emotions your review would be hollow. You are simply knitpicking small things and then spend time talking about how you actually dont have the right to complain about it, (because you dont have the right). 

You seem to have trouble figuring out exactly why DS1 managed to connect its areas more widely and why the later installments dont measure up in this regard. So I will explain.
DS1 have routes that connect areas. It makes sense topographically that the areas would be there but lore-wise its so god damn stupid, cities stacked on cities, crystal caverns, underground lakes with archtrees and burnings depths all within walkingdistance. DS3 gives you the option to warp because now you arent exploring a hill of different civilizations stacked on top of eachother, you are exploring a world, Irythil cant be on top of Lothric castle or viceversa because it makes no sense. To tell the story you know and love to be DS3 they need to expand the universe and fill it with different cultures and detail (which you commended in the review). The story is what connects the areas, the characters binds it all together, you should know that with 50k subs on a darksouls channel.

"I miss that feeling of getting lost, and it being of how complex the world felt, not because I was missing out on a silly mechanic".
Are you serious....This sounds poetic but its so stupid coming from a 'reviewer'. The world of DS3 IS complex, DS3 shouldnt have to rely stuff like this to entertain the player.
Imagine someone saying to the dev team of DS3 "Yeah I walked around in circles for hours in DS1 because I had trouble finding my way, i had a blast, is there any way to incorporate that in the next DS?"

And the weapons, man the negativity from you is crazy. You start of by saying youve PVPed for 2 years and then you complain about the diversity of weapons. Its a medival game with swords, shields and staffs. There is a limit to how many variations you can have without turning this into a fucking ninjagame. You complain about the movesets being similar but neglect all the awesome flipping and sliding attacks from tons of weapons. The awesome weaponarts from bossweapons. PVP isnt the focus of this game and yet its kept so many people entertained for years. Look at the awesome footage you have where knights run around fighting with blessed swords, spears and greatswords. 

What other game outside the DS franchise can you compare DS3 this to? Who did this better? You have no other reference.

Im trying to be contructive, not negative. You love the franchise so much that you consider it a work of gods. And are holding it to wierd af standards. The people who created this are just regular dudes and gals sitting in a room discussing cool ideas. Knock yourself down a peg m8.

textDisplay: Hey Paragon, if you're still interested in a souls type of setting but in a different genre, I highly recommend reading the "Book of the New Sun" series by Gene Wolfe. It is a "science-fantasy" setting if that makes sense but it is very similar to souls in tone and depth. There is an ungodly amount of symbolism and archaic language in the books as well as a lot of gray area for the reader to make interpretations out of. Thank god I 'found' your channel a few weeks ago. I mean, I knew about you a lot longer, but you were 'one of the DS youtubers' to me. Now that I've watched a lot of your videos, I am happy to have checked you out. What you say about Ds3 in most of your videos is just sooooooo refreshing in comparison to the stuff most other Youtubers say about it. This extreme negativity without any kind of regard for the things the game did well tired me out so much, I stopped looking at most of the DS channels I see. 
You've really refreshed my faith in the community, not only because you are one of the few people to not mindlessly shit on Ds3, but also because the way you react to stuff in the game, especially in your playthrough of the Ringed City, is relatable and, I'll reuse the word here, refreshing to see. You are one of the few guys that I felt genuinely reacted to what was happening in regards to the series and the world coming to an end. It seemed like you actually had feelings for the game and were not negatively inclined towards the DLC just because 'it's DS3'.

So thanks a lot for making the last 'moments' of this game and the Dark Souls series as a whole feel... I don't know how to say it. Good again? Basically, I couldn't actually feel the 'sadness' or melancholy over the loss of this series that it deserved, because for me, the constant negativity I had to hear was present in every thought I had about the game. Thank you for letting the end of this series that I invested a lot of hours into not feel like a bad memory!

textDisplay:
It's a shame that the best level to PvP is 140 or 150. Below level 135, I felt my pyro had to try SUPER HARD to just be equal with quality builds. There is a way to get your sorcerer to be insanely strong at level 50 (have 60 intellect and melt faces), but... that's a bit of a niche thing. And, at 120, every player has the exact same build and use pretty much the same exact 5 weapons. Boring!

I love the PvP in this game, and the PvE; I just wish that there were more... "live-looking" areas, such as the swamp. So much of the game is so monochromatic. I also wish that we had more un-broken armor pieces. The Deserter set is beautiful, but... it's all mangled.

As far as invasions; I do agree. As a first time Dark Souls player, doing my first invasions in Dark Souls 3 left me really frustrated. How in the world was I supposed to kill off 3 guys or 4 guys at the same time (lol, on my pyro)? I didn't invade again until maybe 100 hours later into the game. And unfortunately, it took a while for me to even be able to start doing PvP because I didn't realize that intellect builds were shit at level 120. 

Oh, and not to mention that as an intellect user, you have to beat Dark Souls 3 a whopping 3 times just so that you are on-par with a melee person. Gotta get yourself that Sage Ring +2. It's really unfair that they didn't just drop a Sage Ring +3 in one of the DLCs. Sure, I'd already do a +2 run through on my characters so I could collect all of the weapons from bosses... but I don't like feeling that I "have" to do so just for that stupid sage ring +2.

I'd give Dark Souls 3 10/10. It's by far one of my favorite games of all time.

textDisplay:
Dark Souls 3 is a trash game. They threw away all the ingenious, bold design choices from Demon's Souls and Dark Souls 1, and made it closer to Fallout 4 or Zelda or some shit. It's a pretty game, good music, a few interesting enemies/bosses, some cool areas and what not. But overall the world/level design is terrible and linear, warping gives it immediate easy mode. They took the dodging/rolling system from Bloodborne and applied it (where it doesn't belong) making stamina an overly-plentiful resource and (by fucking with equip load) eliminated all of the variety in builds from earlier games. In DS3 everyone is pretty much just a dude with a big weapon who rolls and dodges a lot. Also, most of the bosses were "puzzle bosses" similar to Bed of Chaos where you just pull a lever to defeat them. They redeemed themselves a little with the incredible DLC bosses, but still, DS3 seems like a huge downgrade and an embarrassing fall from grace after timeless masterpieces like DS1 & Bloodborne.
Just glance at the active player numbers to see the confirmation about DS3's failure. Yes, it's a good game, but not a masterpiece, not timeless or absorbing, the player base fell sharply after release and now basically no one is playing DS3, meanwhile the player base for DS1 has been large and enthusiastically active for more than half a decade.

textDisplay: For me 3 falls squarely in the middle of the series. I like it more than Dark Souls 1 and Bloodborne, but less then Demon's and Dark Souls 2. It has a number of problems, from the gameplay being way to fast for a Souls game, the lack of support early game for non-melee builds, and other such flaws that have been talked about to death, but also the fact that some areas really don't feel like they were designed for shields, which strikes me as odd considering that shields are a core part of the franchise, and this game seems to forget that at points. (like Nameless King, probably my least favorite boss in the game) As well as the fact that it has a number of the lore problems that Dark Souls 1 has (the pointless presence of the dragons, the focus on Gwyn, despite him not being all that interesting, the constant doom and gloom of the characters) but at least it has less repetition then DS1 or BB, and while it has just as nonsensical a world as those two, it justifies it far better then those two games did.

textDisplay:
I want to see how people respond to this opinion of mine. 
(Keep in mind I love Dark Souls 3 and still give it a 7/10, but just hear me out)
The reason Dark Souls 3 is my least favorite Fromsoft game (Aside from the shit PVP, stale abundance of weapons, lack of interesting characters compared to the previous titles, too many references to the older games and lazier world design) is that the game has a complete identity crisis.

What I mean by this is that Dark Souls 3 feels as if it can't decide whether it's a Dark Souls game, or a Bloodborne game. As someone else on Steam said
(here's the full post http://steamcommunity.com/app/374320/discussions/0/365163686085640733/)
This game isn't Dark Souls, it's Bloodborne Knight Edition.

This is why I've hated Dark Souls 3 so much on gameplay. Because the author of that post is right, the enemies and bosses are incredibly, ridiculously fast and attack so rapidly. Some of them even attack with absolutely no telegraphing for you to avoid the attacks. Meanwhile, your character is slow and sluggish, takes forever to swing a f**king straight sword let alone the slow rolling and absurd vitality system.
Examples of this would be the stick holding hollows, corvians, dogs, and even bosses like Gael and Dragonslayer armor. Everything is fast and aggressive, and while I absolutely love that style of gameplay, it doesn't work when your character is far slower and more bulky. And sure, there's plenty of dark souls pro's who can beat the game without any hits, and as Pargon shows, beats bosses like the Souls of Cinder and Gael without being hit, but you CANNOT expect every player in the world to have that level of ability or to have the same level of enjoyment.
Bloodborne is my favorite Fromsoft game despite it's flaws because it's so fast and aggressive and fun to play! I love dodging around my opponent and slashing at them with a fast weapon while they viciously try to tear me apart. But it simply wouldn't work if the player wasn't as fast as they were.

I think if Dark Souls 3 had your character be as fast as the Bloodborne hunters were and made the way we swing our weapons more realistically (more fast) but didn't have the benefit of the rally potential mechanic, it would have balanced it perfectly. Now builds that don't turtle behind shields feel rewarded because they're quick and dangerous like their enemies and are rewarded for playing like that.

textDisplay:
DS3 is a very strong 8 out of 10.  
- Phenomenal combat system that's very poorly balanced (as described in this video)
- Excellent bosses for the most part (I actually really like the perceived worst boss of DS3 and have several that are less unique and interesting deserving of a lower spot)
- Uninspired weapon selection (as mentioned in the review there's an illusion of mass choice but in reality that's not the case)
- Terrible Story.  This genuinely brings the score down for me.  I understand and appreciate that analysis of the environments is great for some of the hardcore players out there.  Its not for your average player.  I've played through DS3 twice without looking at lore videos and I got nothing but confusion from the story.  It is a definitive downside in the same way that Destiny's 3rd party resource for lore is a downside on that games storyline.  If your storytelling is too cryptic for the majority of your playerbase then you've failed to craft a good story. 
- Death is too punishing.  This is a downside because I don't appreciate having my time wasted.  My issue here isn't the loss of souls or that souls are lost perm after 2 deaths before recovery.  No, my issue is 100% with the run distances between SOME bonfires and their bosses.   Running through 3 minutes of content or fighting through it for the 20th time to attempt a boss is NOT fun and NOT rewarding nor does it enhance the experience.  Dark Souls as a franchise should respawn you at the boss door on death or have less than a 30 second travel time.  I gave it a pass on the original game but by DS3 this has become unforgivable.   Don't waste your players time by boring them.  That's never been good game design and it continues to be poor design in DS3.
- Item spam/cryptic items/features.  Not telling the player information is flat out bad design.   Having to alt/tab out of the game to understand what something means/does is bad.  If DS as franchise had something in game to learn this stuff I'd give it a pass but it doesn't.   Trial and error of things in games CAN be fun but this isn't an example of that done right.   

I strongly recommend everyone buy or check out Dark Souls 3.  Its been my favorite game of 2017 (I bought it this year as my first ever Souls game) but it has some heavy flaws holding it back from true greatness as well.   I'm not a pvp player so I can't comment on that side of things.  I had no real issue with invasions in the pve game and while I didn't feel they really enhanced anything I can say they didn't detract either.  It was simply a fine way of making the world feel more real.  Perfectly acceptable idea especially since you didn't get spammed with invasions constantly.  If it was too frequent it would be a major problem since that impacts the natural flow and difficulty scaling the main game is trying to create.

textDisplay: I like your analysis of the game, and I respect your years-long journey of the series, but I disagree on a semantic level with the general community's stance on the storytelling. Giving some general statements in item descriptions and planting some visual cues in backgrounds along with vague dialogues is very artistic and very unique stylistically for the medium, but it's not storytelling. It can be very enjoyable and liberating for people to experience a game/story in this fashion, but flinging mostly unformed ideas and concepts against a wall and letting everyone make their own story of it all doesn't meet the criteria for me. I know that it's an unpopular stance and the community has shouted down this kind of opinion before, but ultimately if they are satisfied I have no problem personally with them or the series; I simply don't recognize a lack of narrative as a narrative.

textDisplay:
Great review! I'm glad you're able to see the game objectively and not just throw shade on it because that's what all the sheep like to do. Popular opinion is that DS1 and BB had the best level design of the Soulsborne games, which I agree with. DS3's levels are more linear and lack the level of exploration and discovery of the two aforementioned games. But after your first playthrough, the mysteries of DS1 and BB's worlds have been revealed for the most part, leaving you to complete the laundry list of things required to progress in each subsequent NG. 

I think DS3's maps were designed with PVP invasions in mind. As the last(for now) Souls game, it has to be able to sustain the playerbase long after the game is released. Did they succeed? That's debatable. I would have wanted more invadable areas, more location-based covenants, and as you mentioned, more balanced invasion mechanics. That whole area right underneath Nameless King? WTF, Miyazaki, that could have been an epic duelling spot! 

The Undead Arena's maps are super bland. From could have polished those up a bit. But like you, I continue to play. Visually, DS3 is the most skillfully executed installment of the Souls series to date, which is a definite factor in me playing this over replaying DS1 or 2. It's faster, being somewhere between DS2 and BB, and even if the build diversity is somewhat limited, I'm still experimenting with builds and coming up with new fashions almost every week. 

I love this game, and I think my Steam profile shows it, lol(just broke 2000 hrs)! Aside from little breaks for The Division and For Honor, DS3 is literally the only game I've played since it released.

textDisplay:
Good vid, Paragon. I agree with most of your points. My biggest issue with DS3 is that it has gone into mainstream format, while at the same time, still trying to present itself as a super-challenging game to survive through. By mainstream format, this means dumbed down area transition, more linearity, easier ways to deal with enemies, a more loose PvP system instead of a more studied one, subsequent patches which kept altering PvE elements into an even easier mode (for instance the Angels in Dreg Heap became weak to Hidden Body, phantoms can now attack Vilhelm, etc), subsequent playthroughs offering little reward and no enemy alteration, and the game in itself forcing you to move to higher NGs just to gather rings, and too much nostalgic copy-paste and too many unneeded nods to previous titles which made DS3 look more of a rehash in many occasions.
The game is still challenging alright but it simply builds on the fact of your ignorance of boss movesets and enemy placement; it eventually plateaus into a repetitive scene of purely personal choice of redoing everything again.
My second biggest issue, however, and one that is far more important to the Souls community at this point, is the improper balancing in a lot of things when it comes to PvP. The invasion system, the inability to invade even when area boss is dead, the useless covenants, the absence of a Dragon Covenant, the nerfed elements that shouldn't have been nerfed like that (like seed and acid surge), the hitbox issues, the copy-pasted arenas (ok the arenas were freebies but still), and ultimately, no real reward for a pvp-focused player after having amassed all the needed Pale Tongues, Forked Tongues, Concord Ears, Human Dregs, and Vertebra Shackles. And the arena's badge system is useless.

Doesn't mean DS3 is a bad game, on the contrary; I really love it, despite its flaws. Thanks again for your vid!

textDisplay:
I have small gripes about the dark souls story, and the writing, and this comes from me, not as a gamer/player, but some who also writes, creates, and enjoys stories cut from a similar cloth.

I'm just going to give one example here, so that it can be a reference to other things like it, within the Dark Souls franchise.

I am perfectly fine with Man's age being an age of Dark, that was suppressed by Gywn actions, and continues to be suppressed by others, who in one way or another, carry his will, whether that is their intention or not. I am also fine with the question of whether the age of Dark is even a good thing. We know it was only a matter of time before its arrival, even despite the powerful resistance it was met with... and we know that the Dark and Humanity are one in the same... but that never implied that it was good, only that men's age, and the age of Dark are the same. It actually make a lot of sense for characters to question the inherent nature of Dark.

What am I not okay with? Well, from my understanding, the further I tread from Gywn's kingdom of Sunlight and Fire, the more Dark I find. Eventually, I discover the abyss. Seems logical. The game makes a point out of making these things opposites; Sunlight to the Abyss, Fire to Dark. Then suddenly the Profaned Flame comes in. At first, I am very interested. I want to know more of why this thing breaks the mold. Similar the First Flame, it burns away at people's souls, yet "the abyss can be seen in it." The First Flame requires powerful souls to stay lit, but the profaned flame burns on with complete disregard for any kindling. In fact, putting it out seems to be impossible.

And these questions are never answered.... they aren't even touched on. The game shows you that Fire and Dark are different extremes on the same spectrum. But then they give you the Profaned Flame,  which isn't even a middle ground, is just borrowing parts of both extremes, and then gives you 0 context on how to understand. It defies everything, and it only does so, so that you'll think its cool.... and maybe because they realized that giving you a dark coal wouldn't make sense, so they tried to make "abyss fire" a thing, and made a "story" around it, which failed to actually present not only its own story, but to add anything to the overall story of Dark Souls as well.

To summarize my problem: It exists, and contributes nothing. Its like asking "How loud does a baby frog croak?" only to realize that tadpoles do not croak. It's a trick. You think about it, but then you are told the answer, nothing meaningful transpires.

Overall I think ds3 is a good game. It had some elements to it that really annoyed me but overall I liked it. It has by far the best bosses in the series in my opinion. textDisplay: While I understand not liking DS1 and 2 gear making a return you have to read between the lines. This is the final age of fire. With lore and people from all lands converge in a unique land of lothric. From our bountiful goddess kidding in the cathedral of the deep and inspiring the creation of another dragon slayer. To the mad covenant founded by our dear Lucatiel. This is the final age, not just an age of fire, but the age of answers as well. Its almost majestic to see the civil war in the game. Those who wish the age to go on, old, dying, or forgotten in Farram's case (Nameless king), and faithful. Then lose who would see it ended, Young, usurpers, sorcerers. While yes to many this seems like a unnecessary love letter to me and a few others this is what we sought, the answers that had been denied to us from the past games, an ending to one of the greatest sagas in gaming history. But thats just my thoughts, whats yours?

textDisplay:
Dark Souls 3

Pros - Graphically pleasing.

Cons - Imbalanced Character Class. Linearity makes every playthrough stale. Monotonous color palette. Weakest re-iteration. Large group of enemies encourage players to run past everything. Enemies attack track. Game mechanics were built to counter players' stratagem. Rigged AR. Straight swords overshadow every other weapon class. iFrames are ridiculous. Poise is subtle and involuntary. Stamina Regeneration unbalanced. Must rest at Bonfire to refill limited set of consumables. Unbalanced weight tiers. Ring tiers with inadequate increases. Matchmaking scales off of equipment. Half-baked weapon arts/skills that consume FP. Magic (Pyro/Miracle/Sorcery) underpowered even with high stat investments. Underplayed Covenants.






Verdict: Straightforward, but Lukewarm

Just my take on the story, I really loved how Dark Souls 2 told its lore. DS2 seemed to provide that little extra that gave me a bit more of a focus, maybe because I suck at creativeness-stuff ;P. I think to me, even though Nashandra was a disappointingly easy fight mechanically, she meant so much more to me in terms of a major twist leading to some decent closure in a nice way. In contrast to the soul of cinder, and extension to Gael, I dislike the simple closure of not much. I dislike this normal closure so much I always prioritize changing the ending to make it favor the fire keeper, just because I love the closure I get from that alternate ending. Saying that, the choice to craft your ending in both games in their own slight differences is amazing.

Even though DS2 was more linear and yet gave me more closure in a way, DS3 just flowed so well in its individual arc - like stories, Abyss Dweller, Yhorm, Pontiff, all of these little stories were so amazing by themselves.

textDisplay: The ending:  It always bothered me, even going back to the fairy tales, that writers seem to compulsively tack on a: And they Lived Happily Every After to the end of their stories.  Probably because I got spoiled in the late 70s (Star Wars, Indiana Jones...) with serials that left the ending open for a Sequel, but just because we looked away, doesn't mean everything is tied up in a neat little bow at the "End."  Unless it's a tragedy where everyone dies at the end we don't need Closure.  We think we do, because we've been spoonfed this expectation, but it's not a girlfriend, it's not a parent, it's not a graduate degree in Quantum Mechanics, it's a Video Game,  we played for like a year.  And we will remember Dark Souls 3.  We all will, even without the credits crawl, and the cinematic with Miyazaki saying "Thanks for playing, Good Game" at the end.  Because it is a Good Game that never held our hands, or spoonfed us anything.  That's why we loved it.

textDisplay:
I still prefer dark souls 3 over the other two.
Dark Souls 2 needs no discussion, but Dark Soul 1 does. A lot of flaws you mentioned are quite nitpicky. There is a huge amount of build variety, some just take more skill to use effectively than others. Spells can wreck people's shit if you're good with them. If you're gonna level up intelligence, you better use your brain to fight people. Invasions are annoying, but that's just a product of people being assholes and that's unavoidable. That's like criticising League of Legends as a game for every little cancerous twat who screams at people and harasses. Pvp is 100% skill based. A naked sl1 character can beat a sl100 character of he's way better, just like how a sl1 player can beat the game faster than a sl100 character. These things are problems, but nowhere near as bad as the problems that plague dark souls 1. The limited teleportation later on can cause you to grind through long areas devoid of much interest or enemies. Example, there is no way to avoid going through lower blighttown 3 TIMES in order to complete the game 100% and 2 times just to win the game. Some bosses are so average or bad that it's annoying to fight them. All the stray demons, bed of chaos, pinwheel, moonlight butterfly. The game has some of the best bosses in the series but is by far the most inconsistent with its boss quality. The PC port has terrible graphics and framerate issues unless you use dsfx and the pvp is downright unplayable, with the balance sucking and main strategy being to lag behind a player and backtab them. Poise breaks everything, no way around it. These are larger flaws that are far more obvious, but they still don't really bother me all that much due to the quality of the rest of the game, and the same goes for Dark Souls 3, except it has fewer larger issues. And the whole level design thing, that's just a different approach, and shouldn't be treated as "I liked this thing in dark souls 1, so the sequel must do it the same way. Or it's worse" I they wanted to make the world design the same as dark souls 1 they would have. I would argue that it's just a different experience. I'm not bothered by the linearity. In fact I prefer it. The more time spent travelling in the right direction is less time spent travelling in the wrong direction and being punished for it with enemies out of your league. In fact, I tried to get my little brother to play dark souls 1 and you know why he quit in 30 minutes? Because he had no clue where to go and was bored as a result. Going somewhere in order to find that you shouldn't have gone there in the first place can make it feel like a waste of your time. I'm not speaking for myself here, but I'm sayin that in terms of objective game design quality, it's entirely subjective. Some love it, some hate it. DS3 just chooses not to be that way, but the world still feels interconnected, as old and new locations can be entirely visible from vantage points and the path between them often accessible without a single loading screen, so it feels organic as one area bleeds into the next. It's a different kind of world design, not an objectively worse one. Dark Souls 3 has brought me the most enjoyment, even though I started with Dark Souls 1. Because the visuals, bosses, combat, controls, level design and detail, lore, PvP, I prefer Dark Souls 3 in all these compartments, despite my love for DS1.

textDisplay: I only played ds1 and ds3, and I feel that ds3 is far better game play wise. It was much smoother and actions just feel more natural. But ds1 blows it out of the water in terms of atmosphere and story. Ds3 also relied too much on nostalgia, and honestly From seems to be better with new worlds, which they can experiment and innovate with, instead of the old ones, which have established rules and lore to abide by. On the bosses it's pretty much a tie. Ds3 undoubtedly had some of the best, but so did ds1, and it has the undefeated orstein and smough. They both had their faults, and both had their good things. At the end of the day, I think I'm done with ds3, but I could see going through ds1 again.

textDisplay:
I've always had 2 problems with souls.

1. There's pretty much zero point in being anything other than "weapon fighter man" and choosing some random good weapon and waving it around. None. Magic is garbage. Stealth is almost none existent. Boring af pvp.

2. I don't agree that the invader is at any disadvantage at all. The host is in his world trying to play the game. He's not leveled up. He doesn't have access to all the gear yet. He's still being built. He's not initiating anything. An invader, more often than not, has a finalized build, optimized gear and is choosing to initiate. In other words, you've a professional assassin jumping a half-assed nobody. It's goofy af that the monsters don't even attack the invader imo.

I like souls for the lore. I find most everything else about it trash honestly, esp pvp. Eugh. But I kind of grew up on good, balanced pvp games (MUDs). I'm a bit spoiled.

textDisplay:
i started with dark souls 3 this is what i have to say.
i played it how you reccomended. no help whatsoever. not because i listened to your advice, i didn't find your channel until a week after finishing my first playthrough, but the satisfaction i got from each boss, especially midir, soul of cinder and gael, it got me hooked. i loved almost every boss fight, beggining with me being scared as hell about the amount of rape i was gonna get and leaving me hyped up and ready to go fuck some more shit up after beating them. gael is my favorite boss fight in any game. the hits you do feel like they do damage but also like they don't at the same time, being hit deals a shit ton of damage, but enough so that you can keep going, but still knowing that too many hits like that will screw you over. by the end of the fight, your heart is racing and you just say to yourself, even though you are just a newcomer "this was a good fucking story". now i am waiting for the other two games to go on sale. i am waiting to test my mettle against ds 1 so much. this game means so much more to me, more so than skyrim or the witcher (since they are all similar in my eyes). this game changed my personality to some extent. i feel like it has made me more mature, it has taught me not to attack on every chance you get, to be slow and be patient. and to not give up (of course i will still quit on many things but it still helped a bit XD).  i came to the series expecting to dislike the game, but i actually came to love it.

textDisplay:
I'm not a big PvP player, because I never got good enough at it for the entry cost to stop feeling overwhelming and not worth the time and effort, but I don't think that summoning should be outright disabled when invaded. If a player doesn't have any summoned phantoms at the time of invasion, then I think they should absolutely be able to summon if they find a summon sign.

I do however, agree that the host should not be able to re-summon. So instead of disabling summoning, I think that the total number of phantoms that a host can summon should be locked at the same value as the number of simultaneous summoned phantoms (2, I think?), for the duration of the invasion. That cap should then increase by 1 for each time a new invader appears (in the case of Farron or Aldritch faithfull).

More importantly, I think the friendly-fire for red phantoms is BS. It makes sense for the purple phantoms (that is, after all, the whole point), but red phantoms shouldn't be able to damage each other -- at least, not without some sort of ring or something that allows you to be damaged by other red phantoms.

textDisplay: I fundamentally disagree with the statement that Dark Souls 2 pvp was better, more diverse, and more balanced. It’s still the most comically imbalanced of all Soulsborne titles. One-shot and two-shot builds proliferated. I put over 1000 hours into the pvp alone and I probably fought the same 3 builds 85% of the time. Every so often the meta builds would change when some other broken mechanic or exploit was discovered. Then everyone would do that build for a few months. People remember Dark Souls 2 with fondness for these exploits and imbalances because it was so stupidly easy to win by exploiting these broken mechanics. Dark Souls 3 removed most of these exploits and balanced magic. Now that it’s more difficult to one-shot your opponent with CSS from 100 ft away you all cry out, dumbly, that magic is no longer “viable.” Now you have to actually have skill to succeed with magic. Wow imagine that! I have 9 builds in Dark Souls 3, including magic builds, a faith build, and a pyro build. My win rate is extremely high. Your refusal to adapt and accept you can’t just mash the same button combo for cheap victories over and over is why you feel it’s not viable. And this is coming from a guy who used the same broken shit in Dark Souls 2 to destroy opponents. At least I can be objective and say that Dark Souls 2 pvp wasn’t deep it was as basic and casual as it gets and thank fuck that era is over. And don’t even get me started on soul memory ffs. Good riddance.

textDisplay:
Dark Souls 3, to me, is much like Dark Souls 2: a great game on its own, but not really a worthy successor to the first game. And I don't think there ever can be a worthy successor. Dark Souls was never meant to have a sequel. If you pick an ending at 1, they are pretty final: choose to link the flame, and the world continues until it starts fading again (the next NG+ cycle almost serves as a sequel in a way if that's the case) and if you choose to abandon the flame, the age of man begins and everyone ends up killing one another for humanity. Plus, couple this with the fact Miyazaki hates doing sequels and it wasn't his decision to keep the Souls games going... It really shows in Dark Souls 3. 

Look at all of the fan service in 3. There is an immense amount of it (fan service isn't inherently bad, but too much shows a lack of creativity) and it almost shamelessly shoves it down your throat with no real reason for it to exist in the world. I think this was Miyazaki just playing it safe. I genuinely don't believe he poured much love into this game as he did the first game. The fact most of the stories are still left open ended tells me that he never intended for them to be explained (like many of us were hoping for pre release). On top of that, the shameless rewrites (glaring at you Fillianore...) are a clear indication he stopped caring. 

The NPCs also suffer from this. None of them are as interesting or heart wrenching as say Siegmeyer's sinking into depression from DS1 or the infamous ending to our dear Sun Bro. Siegward is just Siegmeyer fan bait with an out of place twist at the end. Anri's waifu story comes somewhat close to being something, but ultimately doesn't make much sense when it starts tying into the Usurp the Fire ending and I think is just shock for the sake of shock. "Oh no, I have to kill my friend to get this ending! *audible gasp*".

Dark Souls 3 is easy. Well, until you get to Ariandel Chapel or the Dreg Heap.
Dark Souls 3 is still a great game imho. Looks awesome, plays so well, interesting quest lines, great execution, and fan service callbacks which make the 3rd n final game in the series a great send off.

Heck I'd have settled for a mere mention of the rings, map flames and the DLC rewards over you putting yourself through a no-death and like 10 straight NG+ runs (It ain't fun getting one-shot by most late-game bosses.)

That single part of this one shows me that you at least took on board what people said and had the spark one needs to turn criticism into something positive and complimentary to you as a creator. Now with all that said, this one was super well done and continues to be one of my favourite Completionist videos to date.

textDisplay: so ive been with this series since it started off as demon souls and i couldn't beat it, my ex did though and he got platinum for it on ps3 and when i watched him play it, ohhh man the anger at all the deaths was real lol. next game dark souls and again i couldn't beat the game. that kept going until dark souls 3 came along. yeeeep, thats how i knew the game was easier lol. i also beat bloodborne which i always thought was the easy dark souls to begin with until they made dark souls 3. i love the series though and i know bloodborne isn't from the same company but i see people calling it all "soulsborne" so im shoving it in with the souls games, but im kind of glad they made atleast one of them slightly easier for those people who do better when games don't go from 0 to 100. starting off with bloodborne then going from dark souls 3 and then 1 (lol i know right?) is like going from 0 to 30 to 60 to 100, that gradual increase is sometimes needed. the games are still hard too and really it's because of how the game works rather than enemies just being harder to beat. you can't just hit right trigger and kill everything in sight, you have to slow it down and watch patterns and actually block attacks. then theres the invasion aspect (which i hate btw, im not a big pvper so when it happens i just kind of get discouraged) which makes it harder, how the save system/bonfire system works, the item and weapon system, and not to mention that when you use the bonfire or leave and come back, all of the enemies come back to torment you again, its like you just back tracked just to do it again. all of that is what makes these games hard. ive died so many fucking times that honestly, i feel like not being hollow is a power-up like mario's fire flower lol. but if you practice and just keep playing the game you'll know all the enemies moves and can easily defeat them. i did that with one area in bloodborne so i could farm it (the warty witch bosses area) not only for items but for blood points or w/e they're called, the name escapes me atm. im currently trying to beat dark souls 1 and then ill move on to 2 and hopefully i can get 100% on all 4 of the games one day. im glad these games are hard though, i dont like just pressing 1 button and winning all the time, shit gets boring. it's actually helped my gaming skills, see i used to be real good at games when i was like 4 or 5, i mean i knew all the mario secrets and back then we didn't have the internet to find em out, but now im all "out of shape" and the soulsborne games are the perfect way to get into "shape" again. i also never knew about the no death and no bonfire bonus of those inviso wings and now i REALLY wanna beat the game 100%, well beat it without dying or the bonfires. i like a good challenge in my games, it stimulates my brain. i get bored so easily from depression and A.D.D that i always try to create challenges for myself in games and now that i know about those wings im so trying it.

textDisplay: I do not want to seem like some snob popping off on your video, but 66 hours is way too low. The average playthrough of the game for first-time players is between 40-60 hours and you got everything. I platinumed the game in about 100 hours but I also had several hundred hours of online play in 1 and 2. This video is obviously a few months old and I'm not gonna say "pics or it didn't happen" however that number does not seem right to me. I'm new to the channel and I think I saw you did this for the other games so maybe I'm not properly informed on how much you played the other ones. However, on a note that isn't pretentious, the video was fantastic in the way you explained the game. The first of the series will always be my favorite for its more unforgiving nature and the fight with Knight Artorias but, this video was a breath of fresh air seeing my opinion wasn't alone. Playing the series so much my friend group had become filled with just dark souls elitists and they didn't see this game in the same light as the first so it's nice to see someone making great content for a game I personally loved. Cheers!

textDisplay:
Correction: Halflight, Spear of the Church is not the only boss in the series that summons other players.

Dark Souls 2 had the Looking Glass Knight that did the same.

Only problem is, there was no real incentive to let yourself summon ala the covenant Spears of the Church. Thus, it ended up being NPCs being summoned a lot of the time.

Also, if you include Demon's Souls as part of the series, which it is in a meta Soulsborne level, the Old Monk from Stage 3-3 did the same, and was decently active back in the day.

So while the idea is cool, and well executed here, it is not their first time doing this.

textDisplay: Dark Souls 3 was a great place to start for new comers. This was my first game in the action RNG genre I played completely. I started very badly where I needed help from my brother to beat all bosses in my first playthrough. After multiple playthroughs, I became better at it and I managed to beat all in-game bosses at level 1 in NG+7, plus Sister Friede, Midir, and Demon Prince in the DLCs. The game has so much replay value that it provides room to learn new tricks to fight bosses, new ways to traverse the environment, and to explore weapon builds and fashion souls. Overall, this game is one of my favorites since it is challenging, fair, and it has a deep lore in the story despite that I have to work hard to understand it. I enjoy the challenge in Dark Souls although this one is much tougher than DS3. In the future, I may plan to play DS2 to complete the Dark Souls trilogy experience.

textDisplay: The lore was section near the beginning was wrong. The linking of the fire was a way of unnaturally extending the rule of the gods, which Gwyn first did because he didn't want humanity to enter their own age of dark, he was afraid of losing his power, and did a bunch of stuff to keep humanity down and basically used as fodder to perpetuate his rule. It's sorta implied or maybe even sort of outright stated that Gwyn is the reason the undead curse exists. He was basically a reaaaal douche bag.  The natural progression of the world of Dark Souls was to be the Age of Ancients, where the Ancient Dragons ruled, the Age of Fire, where the gods ruled, the Age of Dark, where humanity ruled, and then whatever came next, possibly the Age of Deep, which Aldrich foresaw. Instead, because of Gwyn's actions, the world has been in a perpetual Age of Fire since the first game.

textDisplay:
It is a pity that not everyone will seek out and discover the well hidden and buried narrative that Dark Soul's builds into its world, however I think it would be impossible to achieve the same atmosphere and tone if they added more exposition. You see a key theme throughout the Soul's series is death and decay, you and the world around you are all aged to the point of breaking down, and rarely will you visit an area like Anor Londo which adds contrast. This lends to the idea that almost all of the knowledge about the world has also faded away along with the inhabitants and you can only gain glimpses of the past through small scraps of information you find or learn from infrequent conversation with the few left alive or un-hollowed. 

It wouldn't make sense for your character's journey to go and read a bunch of books or something either, even though you may point to places like the Archive's which would be an easy place to just pack in a lot of exposition. So while it would be better for some players if there were a more clear narrative, it lends to the key themes and core mechanics to have a less complete story, one that you have to piece together for yourself and may never get a full picture because so much of the world has already been lost to time.

textDisplay:
Not sure why you think it's a shame that some gamers won't get to experience the full part of the story. If someone is not the type to be interested in finding out everything they can about a well crafted game, then they likely aren't someone who will care about being spoon-fed the same information anyways. They would just be in it for the gameplay. I don't think I want any aspect of the game to be dumbed-down because that would only serve to make this game more like the rest. I already don't like how people have caught on in Dark Souls 3 that you can just summon 3 phantoms and plow through the game rather than having patience and learning how to play well.

One of the best things about this game and why it was so critically acclaimed when dark souls 1 came out was how you just got dumped in a world. It's not the game's duty to show you what is going on, you are just a part of that world and anything you experience or see is mostly what you make out of it yourself. You could go through and kill everyone you meet and wouldn't know it was the wrong thing to do, since you get loot! 

The item descriptions and placements of items literally MAKE this game unique from every other RPG action adventure campaign story based set piece showcase blagh blagh blagh. You can learn so much about what all is going on while you explore and it makes for a very nice pace of discovery if you are even just the slightest bit patient.

textDisplay:
After hearing an remix in 2016 I got curious about the original and stumbled into the lore, music and watching the boss fights as an outsider thinking that I wasn't cut out for the games.  But my curiosity got the better of me and when Dark Souls 3 went on sale for less than $20.00 I took the gamble and got it in December of last year.  Sadly my dive into to lore spoiled the boss tricks, but not the quality of them.

200+ hours later, one completed playthrough (just shy of 150 hours) and a fairly far second playthrough later on a new character as a Pyromancer (I beat Champion Gundyr and Champion's Gravetender/Greatwolf today).  Needless to say I'm excited for the DS1 remaster (I don't need to get the original port and the mess that it was now) and want a PS4 Pro just to play Bloodbourne now (probably some other games as well, but that's more to justify getting a PS4 if I'm being honest).  DS3 is up there with Pokemon Super Mystery Dungeon (the main series Pokemon games as well) and the original Roller Coaster Tycoon (as well as RCT2, RCT3 and RCT Classic on mobile) for me as one of the best video games I've ever played.

The only boss that I haven't beaten yet is Midir, in fact I haven't even tried to fight the boss myself other than several failed co-op raids as a summon.  But the rest I have, and stinkers aside the overall quality seems to be the best of the games in how consistent the quality of them is, it's not like the other games where you have some truly terrible bosses (Bed of Chaos, most of the uninspired DS2 bosses, the Asylum Demon clones, Pinwheel).

But my top 5 bosses are;
1. Slave Knight Gael
2. Abyss Watchers
3. Dancer of the Boreal Valley
4. Nameless King
5. Pontiff Sulyvahn

textDisplay: In response to people's distaste for the way the story is laid out. The dark souls story presentation went from one of my least favorite parts to one of the best after finishing it. Everything is explained rather realistically if you think about it. Your just as new to this world as your character probably is due to how long he's been resting. So your not just experiencing the world, your character is too. locals don't exposition dump you because your just a random unkindled it wouldn't make sense to waste their breath. The game knows your not gonna pay attention the first time and instead kill everything in your path until you reach the flame. It paints you as a monster killing blindly way more effectively than other games because it's actually your fault. It mocks how predictable you are by telling this story through designing the game to guide (not force) you into making that choice to kill ignorantly. Not some cutscene saying "look how bad you are with this random explaination you couldn't possibly know about prior" and because it gives you that option to stop and read to realize what your actually doing and killing it makes YOU feel guilty and responsible. Even you quiting the game in rage is supposed to symbolize your in-game character as going hollow. This story felt more like my story even though it wasn't  because it didn't feel like I was controlling  someone else. I can go on and make this way more convincing but that'd be too much effort for a YouTube comment so there's the rushed general explanation :P

textDisplay:
This, mechanically, feels the most well made of the dark souls games (except for poise).  But, my main issue, and I've had it since launch, is the linearity.  The previous souls games dropped you in a central spot and said "Alright, have fun."  This one guides you.  It puts you on your goal from the start, which can seem incredible, like the whole "This is what I'm striving for" thing, or it can be depressing.  It was streamlined for new players by making it linear, and barely straying from it's defined straight line.
EDIT: Also, there's so many callbacks to Dark Souls 1.  It feels a lot like "Eh, remember this?  Eh? Eh?"

textDisplay:
Thats weird, I think its the first time I hear that DS3 was considered easier than the other games? Personally I thought it was about on par with the others, and the hardest it gets is definitely harder than any of the previous games, except maybe Bloodborne. The combat feels more aggressive overall, and the bosses get really wild and hectic. Also, the tutorial's boss, Iudex Gundyr, was probably the hardest first boss of the series, I felt that was a really bold move to put a legit fight like that right at the start of the game! I mean, bloodborne had something similar going on with Father Gascoigne, but you had a lot more room to explore and practice, and even level up before fighting him.
I think its less that the game itself is easier, and more that fans of the series have grown accustomed enough to the games that new games can never be quite as difficult as the first few ones were.

textDisplay:
Man... the difficulty has always been vastly overrated. It takes trial and error, and patience. Good game sense helps evade *all* traps that are in it, they all have tells and can be handled via cautious approach. People are just too used to the freedom to save anywhere and reload infinitely, or very generous checkpoints that just toss you back into any challenge over and over again. 

Dark Souls 3, imo, is about the same difficulty as the others. It just has a more mainstream presentation.

textDisplay:
So this may be random but i want to go on a little spiel: i havent watched the completionist for a few months now. Not because i dont enjoy it, this channel is what made me myself a completionist and i absolutely love  just about every episode you’ve ever done. Its that i have an issue of taking other people problems and making them my own emotionally. I cant enjoy a youtuber’s content if i think they suffer as they make it. Honestly my watching the show less and less started when i went to your panel at the last retropalooza. It was then i found out just how stressful and taxing on you your job is. Then there was the (stupid) outcries about broken bonds and sponsors- look the bottom line is that for a long time i’ve been needlessly worried about things i cant control. Idont expect you to see this, but i wanted to put it out there. I hope this year you’re able to do this channel and have fun doing it. I wish you the best, keep being awesome, because everything you’ve done, and everything you’ve endured, has made you someone i truly revere.

textDisplay:
I do love this game but it has its fair share of problems. It is the most linear of the game, poise was removed, cast times are too long for a lot of spells and the fp system frustrates me. 

There is a clear path in the game with only small detours the whole time. I get that fp is meant to limit battle arts but implementing it with magic broke the whole system - making sorcery underpowered in an attempt to balance and pryomancy overpowered. A timed charge system for battle arts would have fit better. The increase in focus on movement makes sorcery casting in particular way too long to be usable and with the removal of poise it feels like spamming is a valid tactic a lot of the time.

textDisplay:
Strange thing. DS3 was the easiest? For me, DS3 is the only Dark Souls i wasnt able to finish. I am not that big of a completionist in this type of games, so a single or maybe a NG+ Finish is enough for me.

But Dark Souls 3 put me in a state... that i got really lost. My last location was the Cathedral with the 2 Giants in it. But... then i found a big door and thought: "Cool, the next boss", just to discover, that it was a loop back to the bonfire (and not even a good one). So i got stuck there... searching every corner of that building.

Then i searched other locations, like the City, but i already found every corner / tunnel / entrance in that areas... So after something like 10hrs of searching where i have to go, i quitted it. After a few weeks, i tried it again, just to discover, that i am not good enough anymore, to handle these locations and still wasnt able to find my way to continue. So i quitted there again and til now... i never finished it.

Maybe i would have been fine after looking into a guide... but i dont know. Dark Souls was a "search and destroy"-game from the beginning. I got stuck so often, i cant even count it anymore. But at the end i was able to find something new, that led me into the right direction. 

So maybe, because this game wasnt that "all open", i didnt found any new and cool stuff, that held me up to finally discover, where i missed a door/breakable tunnel or something.
