textDisplay:
On top of Vaati being the lore person, we have numerous others who put on comedic content for this dark and dreary game, but my top mention would be Aviators for making some pretty neat music for the souls games on top of his usual blend. Also, Lothric was the one teleporting Lorian around the boss fight with the two.

Dark Souls 3 was the first Souls game I've played, and I fondly remember the time when I overcame the tutorial boss that had a friend of mine quit the game on. I then went on to put a few hundred hours into it to get 100% with just my mouse and keyboard. All the bosses were quite memorable so it's difficult to say any favourites. Iudex Gundyr was a fun, straight up fight early in for me.

I'd have to mention it with starting off as a pyromancer as a fun choice, and that the Great Deep Soul is my favourite dark spell for pretty much anything. Unfortunately, it's a 30 reputation unlock with all those PvP groups that ended up being such a grind. Used it with the Scholar's Candlestick and Izalith Staff for a hard hitting spell that costs very little FP. It's really useful for the first stage of the Nameless King due to the projectiles automatically locking onto the head of the dragon. You'll be knocking it down and out of the fight before you know it. 

Then you can throw in the high level pyromancy to nuke other players or enemies. The Great Chaos Fire Orb being one though it had a rather large FP cost last I used it. Fire Clutch Ring + Witch Ring + Great Swamp Ring + Lloyd's Sword Ring for about at least 62% increased fire damage when I was at it. Replace the fire ones for sorcery variants when you switch between the Great Deep Soul and the standard pyromancy fire balls and spells.

textDisplay:
This game is one of my favorites, and I actually didn't know that this was the last one. I embarrassingly also spent so much goddamn time in the first and the second part right after that. I quit the game for a few months, before eventually going back in and falling in love with it. It's frustratingly hard, but that's the charm of it. The sense of accomplishment from beating a hard boss, to the feeling of heartbreak when you lose 50k souls, which eventually leads to when it happens the 10th time, acceptance immediately, as you just have to keep moving on, and you'll make those souls back soon enough.

As someone who casually played, and hasn't even finished the DLC, I can't imagine doing this. I would be so miserable.

textDisplay:
I don't understand, why people try to make their own criteria for "completing" a game, when there really is only one way to ACTUALLY COMPLETE a game! 

1. Kill every boss(including secret ones) and every non-respawning enemy in the game.
2. Collect every item contained in the game, no matter how important, excluding respawning items (basically every equivalent for Mario's coins, Sonic's rings, DK's bananas, Crash's wumpa fruit etc.)
3. finish every mission/level in the game, while obeying both of the above.

Three simple rules, no more, no less! That is, what COMPLETING a game means!

textDisplay:
I'd argue the enemies are harder than previous iterations, it's just the controls are better and  the interface itself is more user friendly. The crucifixion baddies pretty early on by the poison beetles in DS3 would make very hard foes in Dark Souls 1 and 2 being much faster and harder to dodge than most foes you'd come across short of those pesky swift doggos. There's also the fact that the Dark Souls community had to first adjust to the heavy wiki usage for those who got lost or are stuck and want to find what they can do to make it easier for them or understand what to do next. 

The wikis helped hand hold those who were used to Skyrim level transparency on what to do next. However this cheat sheet if you will basically became streamlined and very quick during Dark Souls 2 and by the time Dark Souls 3 came out it was almost insane how quick the wikis flooded with information that can help you avoid challenges or problems that would otherwise only be possible to do in NG+ thus avoiding confusion, discovery, and challenge caused by intentionally left vaguely explained concepts. So those who might've used the wiki before when they were first starting out may not need the wiki now as they understand how souls games work, but they don't break the habit and at the first apparent dead end they fly to the wiki and ruin the nuanced game play that was intended as well as making the game that much easier.

tl;dr the game is harder if you go in blind compared to going in blind to DS1 or 2, but you got gud in DS 1 and/or 2 or got gud at abusing wikis neither of which mean the game itself is easier or that the dev team messed up. Besides they made a game already for try hards in Dark Souls that's hard even for someone who's good at Dark Souls, it's called Bloodborne lol.

textDisplay:
Jirard, well done for being the biggest BOI and taking on Dark Souls 3. Also make sure you buy Alex a wrap sometime, he's earned it :)

Have to share my own completion nightmare story with one of FROMS games, Bloodborne. After playing the game for sometime I decided I wanted to platinum the game. So I hunkered down and began the journey. It took me quite a while to get everything (Though the DLC I found quite easy in contrast), then I reached the point where I had to complete the Chalice Dungeons. I personally find the dungeons as the most tedious part of the game, so everyday I would set to complete one dungeon and unlock another for the next. I was at the end of the second to last dungeon, with hype running in my system with just one more trophy for my first Platinum in a FROM title and the chance to face a boss I hadn't touched before. Then it happened.....a power-cut. When power returned I found my save was gone, it was probably the most crushing moment in gaming for me. I was so upset I punched a hole in my bed and boy did I scream. To this day I still haven't go that last trophy or platinum for Bloodborne, I dont have the willpower to do the chalice dungeons again after that heartache. Maybe someday I'll muster the heart and 'GIT GUD' enough to tackle it again...or I'll just get bored and have nothing else to do.

textDisplay:
A toast, my friend, of Siegbrau!  To see a series such as this off, there is no finer thing.

As for bosses... that's a tough choice.  Least favorite has to go to Bed of Chaos.  It's less a boss fight and more just... 'make sure you watch your step'.  It's the only boss I felt I had bullshit deaths from, cause the floor collapsed under me.

Most favorite though, that's the hardest one to do.  There are many, many good fights.  But I honestly have to give it to Gwyn, Lord of Cinder.  Now this might be because I have yet to finish Dark Souls 2 or 3, but so far he's holding it.  It's less to do with the actual fight and more with the atmosphere of it.  The look of the arena, the music itself.  Combined with how Gwyn looked and all, it was a lot more of 'I kinda pity this man who sacrificed everything, but in the end all he did was stave off the end a little longer.'  That despite it all, this is what's come of it.  And no matter what, what he tried to save is inevitably lost.  I almost think that it was this that made me choose to link the flame there.

textDisplay:
To me this  game is an absolute Complete It. I have so many hours into it. I've tried doing the craziest shit, like starting a character and maxing out stats one at a time. Like first I put Strenght to 99, and so forth. One of my proudest moments was probably soloing Midir with a Melee character in NG+4. This character is over level 300, and I plan on reaching Max Level with him eventually.
While yes, I would agree, 30 covenant items seem like too much, and something like 15 ou 20 feels like it would be more adequate, consider the following:
Grinding them out of enemies is the devs solution to keep this game playable even after servers die. Jirard, remember the problem you had with Metroid recently? With Medals you couldn't get because of online? That will never happen with this game. Everything that requires online has a detour.
The game will ultimately also give you one or two of those items through each playthrough, so through NG+3 like you were,  you didn't actually need 30, but somewhere around 20 to 25.
And then again, the game doesn't expect you to complete it in such a short amount of time. It expects you to have a covenant on through your playthrough. At times of peak when this game was extremely popular, you could do Sun's Covenant in NG, Aldritches in NG+, Darkmoon in NG++, or any of those mixed and mashed. It still would take you about the same amount of time as grinding, because you're just as likely to fail your mission; but the point is, the covenants expect you to do what the covenants wants you to in coop. You were not meant to grind for them. The grinding is there for when the game is absolutely dead.

textDisplay:
I wouldn’t call DS3 the easiest by design, it just has the best controls in the Souls franchise, and it is also the third installment, by now people know what the series is all about, they’ve conquered the previous games, and they’re familiar with the kind of game it will be.
People forget, one of the reasons DS1 was so hard was the sense of unfamiliarity there was to the gameplay and the mechanics, and how rewarding it was to finally learn how to play the game how it was meant to be played.
When I started DS1 (my first one), I would spam attack, spam rolls, waste resources, upgrade armor (lol) and use weapons I hadn’t upgraded or hadn’t leveled the correct stats for. Sure, the game is very fucking cryptic and who would’ve known you don’t need to level Dex for a big ass Zweihander (whoops).
Playing DS2 was in contrast a lot easier because I knew the mechanics and gameplay of Souls games. I didn’t really like the game, but it still had it’s good moments.
Now, with DS3 I had two previous Souls experiences (and Bloodborne to boot), so at that point I wasn’t looking for a mind-numbingly difficult challenge, there was not much the game could throw to me in terms of difficulty that I couldn’t conquer anymore, which led me to face the new challenges with excitement rather than dread like in previous titles.
The game didn’t get easier, we just got gud.

textDisplay:
I had that same feeling of sadness after finally beating Dark Souls 1.  It was the only one in the series I hadn't beaten yet thanks to the horrors of Blight Town, and the hype surrounding Ornstein and Smough made me hesitant to push forward.  And ya know, they were deserving of that hype.  Had to gain a few levels, learn how to parry in the process, find out Ornstein can't be parried, grind a few more levels, and eventually learn how the bosses work meaning I probably didn't need all those extra levels in the first place but screw it I got 'em let's move on.

But when I faced up against Gwyn, saw his bedraggled corpse flailing about, noticed how easy he was to parry... I felt hollow.  The music was a good fit for the mood I had after mercilessly beating the last boss of the game, last boss of the series to me, to an embarrassing pulp.  There was nothing left for me to attain, no new journey, no horizon to chase.  I had done it.  And there was nothing left.

I suppose challenge runs are still available to me, but never again can I step foot in Boletaria, Lordran, Drangleic, Lothric, or Yharnam without a strong sense of familiarity.  I will be forever trapped playing the same game over and over again, each time losing some of the magic that enraged and then entranced me.  From created something special in the Soulsborne series.   Something that others tried to imitate, still others crafted love letters in the form of games, but none have truly captured the magic that Dark Souls wove.

In the end, I suppose the Linking of the Flame endings represent how Miyazaki came to feel about the series; the first time, it was a grand flame, with strong hope for a magnificent future.  The second linking produced a somewhat smaller flame, but still brilliant and with faith in what was yet to come.  The third linking was tiny; I mean look at us, we barely even catch light.  The Age of Fire is at an end, and no matter how many more times the Fire is linked, it will never be as brilliant as before.  The time has come for a new Age to usher itself in.
